discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
- UPDATE can be granted only on tables and views
- ALTER is valid for tables and sequences but not views.
- REFERENCES can be granted only on tables and views.

Selected Answer: ADE
Select can be given to all.

A. TRUE
B. FALSE. Only Table
C. True. Can also be granted on sequences
D. False. Trick question as alter is system privilege. Alter can be granted on both table and sequences.
E. TRUE
F. False. Insert can be granted to table and synonym

questions.question_text: Which three are true about granting object privileges on tables, views, and sequences? (Choose three.)

choices.C: SELECT can be granted on tables and views.
choices.A: UPDATE can be granted only on tables and views.
choices.F: INSERT can be granted on tables, views, and sequences.
choices.B: DELETE can be granted on tables, views, and sequences.
choices.E: REFERENCES can be granted only on tables and views.
choices.D: ALTER can be granted only on tables and sequences.

choices.C: LEFT OUTER JOIN with self join
choices.D: FULL OUTER JOIN with self join
choices.B: RIGHT OUTER JOIN with self join

questions.question_text:
Examine the description of the CUSTOMERS table:

//IMG//


CUSTNO is the PRIMARY KEY.

You must determine if any customers’ details have been entered more than once using a different CUSTNO, by listing all duplicate names.

Which two methods can you use to get the required result? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
BE is the correct one
You cannot have a COUNT() in a WHERE clause. That is what the HAVING clause is for

questions.question_text:
The SALES table has columns PROD_ID and QUANTITY_SOLD of data type NUMBER.
Which two queries execute successfully? (Choose two.)

choices.E: SELECT COUNT(prod_id) FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 GROUP BY prod_id;
choices.B: SELECT prod_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 GROUP BY prod_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;
choices.C: SELECT COUNT(prod_id) FROM sales GROUP BY prod_id WHERE quantity_sold > 55000;
choices.D: SELECT prod_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 AND COUNT(*) > 10 GROUP BY prod_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;
choices.A: SELECT prod_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 AND COUNT(*) > 10 GROUP BY COUNT(*) > 10;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Answers C & D are correct.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true regarding a SAVEPOINT? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Rolling back to a SAVEPOINT can undo a TRUNCATE statement.
choices.C: Rolling back to a SAVEPOINT can undo a DELETE statement.
choices.A: Rolling back to a SAVEPOINT can undo a CREATE INDEX statement.
choices.D: A SAVEPOINT does not issue a COMMIT.
choices.B: Only one SAVEPOINT may be issued in a transaction.

choices.D: SELECT customer_id AS CUSTOMER_ID, transaction_date AS TRANS_DATE, amount + 100 “DUES AMOUNT” FROM transactions;
choices.C: SELECT customer_id AS “CUSTOMER_ID”, transaction_date AS DATE, amount + 100 “DUES” FROM transactions;
choices.A: SELECT customer_id AS “CUSTOMER_ID”, transaction_date AS “DATE”, amount + 100 DUES FROM transactions;
choices.E: SELECT customer_id CUSTID, transaction_date TRANS_DATE, amount + 100 DUES FROM transactions;
choices.B: SELECT customer_id AS ‘CUSTOMER_ID’, transaction_date AS DATE, amount + 100 ‘DUES’ FROM transactions;

discussion.content:
A,D,E is correct. Tested. Feel free to try

SELECT 'abc' AS "customer_id", Sysdate as "date", 10+100 Dues FROM DUAL; {ASS

SELECT 'abc' AS 'customer_id', Sysdate as date, 10+100 'Dues' FROM DUAL; Fail because single quote for alias and not double quote on date. Alias cannot be in a single quote and date must be in a double quote as date is saved as a datatype

SELECT 'abc' AS "customer_id", Sysdate as DATE, 10+100 "Dues" FROM DUAL; FAIL. No double quote for date

SELECT 'abc' AS "customer_id", Sysdate as TRANS_DATE, 10+100 "Dues AMOUNT" FROM DUAL; PASS

SELECT 'abc' CUSTID, Sysdate TRANS_DATE, 10+100 Dues FROM DUAL; PASS

Selected Answer: DE
IT works 1) with as keyword , 2) with double quote 3) with out ANY quote but NOT WITH SINGLE QUOTE. Tested.

Selected Answer: AD
Based on the question, A, E and E are correct.

Single quotes aren't allowed for column names, and DATE requires double quotes since DATE is a key word.

Selected Answer: AD
A, D, E are correct
